questions.text: What is the correct order for the process of communication?
questions.solution:
The correct order for the process of communication is:

Sender→Message→Channel→Receiver→Feedback

The sender (communicator) is the originator of the message. A message is the information which the communicator transmits to his audience. Channel is the media of communication between the sender and the receiver (e.g., interpersonal communication, mass media, traditional or folk media). The audience who receives, understands, and acts upon the message is called the receiver. Feedback is the reaction to the message which flows from the receiver to the sender.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about mass media?

choices.text: It has increased influence only in below-average educated population
It gives greater support for concentrated programmes
Mass media alone is inadequate in changing human behavior
Mass media reaches the widest population

questions.solution:
The advantage of mass media includes that it has increased influence across all educational levels, especially in above-average educational level.

Mass media includes TV, newspaper, radio, etc.

  • Advantages:
    • It reaches people even in the most remote areas.
    • It gets public attention.
    • It has increased influence across all educational levels, especially in above-average educational level.
    • It gives greater support for concentrated programmes.
  • Disadvantages:
    • One-way communication
    • Impersonal method and no face-to-face contact
    • Mass media alone is inadequate in changing human behavior.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an approach to health education?
questions.solution:
Socio-environmental approach is not an approach to health education.

There are four approaches to health education:

Regulatory approach- external control or laws placed on people by the government. Ex: Child Marriage Act, No smoking in public places, Helmet law

Service approach- government aims at providing health services to the people at their doorsteps. Its drawback is that people will not accept a service, even if it is offered free of cost unless it is based on their felt needs. Ex: Government provided latrines free of cost yet people did not use them because its need was not felt

Health education approach- creates awareness of health needs and problems. Awareness leads to motivation which includes the stages of interest, evaluation, and decision-making. It is followed by acceptance of the new idea which becomes part of his existing values, known as internalization. Ex: Adoption of ORS for diarrhea

Primary health care approach- delivery of health services with the active involvement of people. Principles of community participation and intersectoral coordination are stressed here. Its objective is to help individuals become self-reliant in health matters. Ex: People receive guidance from healthcare providers (Rogi Kalyana Samiti, Mahila Arogya Samiti).

questions.text: In which model of health education does internalization occur?
questions.solution:
Internalization belongs to the motivation model.

There are three models of health education:

  • Medical model: transfer of proven medical information into education. It does not bridge the gap between knowledge and behavior.
  • Motivation model: creates awareness of health needs and problems. Awareness leads to motivation which includes stages of interest, evaluation, and decision-making. It is followed by acceptance of the new idea which becomes part of his existing values, known as internalization.
  • Social intervention model: focuses on changing the social environment which subsequently shapes the behavior of individual and the community.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a principle of health education?
questions.solution:
Drawing conclusions is not a principle of health education.

Principles of Health Education:

Known to unknown means to start where the people are and with what they understand and then proceed to new knowledge.

questions.text: Flannelgraphs, exhibits, and flipcharts are used to demonstrate the effect of injudicious use of antibiotics. What is this method of group communication known as?
questions.solution:
Flannelgraphs, exhibits, and flipcharts belong to the chalk and talk method of group communication, in which the chalk is the visual component.

It is also known as lectures. Flannelgraphs, flipcharts, exhibits, films, and charts come under this method. Disadvantages of lectures are:

  • Minimum interaction
  • Do not stimulate thinking or problem solving
  • Comprehension is dependent on the individual
  • Do not influence behavior directly

questions.text: A group discussion was conducted among villagers to assess their knowledge on personal hygiene. Which of the following statements is false regarding this format of health education?

choices.text: Many different topics can be spoken about in one discussion
A group leader guides the conversation
It can bring about change in the attitude of participants
It usually consists of 6 to 12 people

questions.solution:
A group discussion discusses one topic on its agenda.

Group discussion is an aggregation of people interacting in a face-to-face manner. Exchange of ideas, knowledge, and opinions is done by participants which influence a change in their attitudes.

It usually involves 6–12 people with a group leader who guides the conversation, giving equal opportunity to everyone to voice themselves. In a group discussion, everyone must speak and be open to criticism without interrupting others.

A limitation to this form of health education is that not everyone is open to speaking in public. There is also a high possibility of diversion of the topic of discussion when many people are involved.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about panel discussion?

choices.text: It usually consists of four to eight experts
Members of the audience are invited to take part at the end

questions.solution:
A moderator is required to regulate the panel discussion.

In a panel discussion, 4 to 8 experts have a discussion on a topic in front of an audience. No speeches or order is set beforehand. The audience is invited to take part after the panelists speak and ask questions.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1. Workshop

A. Series of lectures on a subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions
2. Symposium B. Incorporates a variety of methods like speeches, discussions, and may last for half a day to a week.
3. Role play C. Series of meetings emphasizing individual work within the group
4. Seminar

D. Dramatization of social situations for health education
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-A, 3-D, 4-B

A workshop is a series of meetings with an emphasis on individual work within the group. External consultants or experts may be involved.

A symposium is a series of lectures on a selected subject by experts after which the audience is allowed to ask questions (no discussion is involved).

Role play is the dramatization of social situations for health education by those taking part in it.

Seminars are similar to conferences and incorporate a variety of methods like speeches, discussions for health education, which may last for half a day to a week.

questions.text:
All of the following are types of combined audio-visual aids except:
  1. Flannelgraph
  2. Podcasts
  3. Slide-tape combination
  4. Cinema
  5. Tape recorders
questions.solution:
Flannelgraphs, podcasts, and tape recorders are not combined audio-visual (A-V) aids.

Flannelgraph is a rough flannel fixed over a wooden board used for displaying pictures, cut-outs, etc. It is only a visual aid. Podcasts and tape recorders are auditory aids.

Audio-visual aids are classified into three groups:

  • Auditory aids: Radio, tape recorders, podcasts
  • Visual aids: Chalkboards, flannelgraphs, charts, posters, slides
  • Combined A-V aids: Cinema, television, slide-tape combination

questions.text: A Norovirus outbreak occurs in an urban slum where you are posted as the PHC medical officer. Which is the best method to teach the people about ORS?
questions.solution:
The best method to teach an urban slum about ORS is by demonstrations.

Demonstration is a carefully prepared presentation on how to perform a certain task or skill or procedure. It shows the step-by-step process of a task. It arouses interest and incites ‘learning by doing,’ and ‘seeing is believing’ philosophies.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to obtain consensus forecasts among a large number of people?
questions.solution:
Delphi method is a systematic interactive forecasting method, which is used to obtain a consensus forecast among a large number of people. It determines the degree of agreement on a topic.

This can help in setting priorities or selecting alternatives in planning. This method uses questionnaires, which are answered by experts in two or more rounds.

questions.text: What is total communication used for?
questions.solution:
The philosophy of total communication is used in the education of hearing-impaired children.

It requires the incorporation of aural, oral, and manual modes of communication for effective communication with and among hearing-impaired people.

questions.text: In which of the given scenarios would you use the GATHER approach?
questions.solution:
The GATHER approach is mainly used for counseling, like in contraceptive counseling, wherein a person is helped to make a decision about health.

GATHER stands for:

  • G – Greet
  • A – Ask
  • T – Tell options or give answers
  • H – Help in making choices
  • E – Explain everything about the decision
  • R – Return for follow-up

questions.text: SPIKES protocol is for:
questions.solution:
SPIKES protocol is for breaking bad news.

Each letter represents a phase in the six-step sequence.

  • S - setting
  • P - perception
  • I - invitation or information
  • K - knowledge
  • E - empathy
  • S - summarizing or strategizing

Key components of the SPIKES strategy include:

  • Demonstrating empathy
  • Acknowledging and validating the patient's feelings
  • Exploring the patient's understanding and acceptance of the bad news
  • Providing information about possible interventions
